quotes.topic_title: AI, org flattening, and managing models
quotes.text: We need to dissolve the boundaries of these traditional roles and call ourselves builders. I'd love for us to get to the world where that's the title.
quotes.speaker: Julie Zhuo
quotes.context: A reframing of roles in AI-flattened orgs that encourages practitioners to broaden scope and operate as end-to-end builders.

quotes.topic_title: AI, org flattening, and managing models
quotes.text: Management is still really critical. You have a north star, you have a vision, and you're just trying to figure out how to use the resources that you have to get that thing done. Used to be people, but now it's basically models and different models have different strengths. You have to assemble the Avengers so that you can use the right tools for the right purposes.
quotes.speaker: Julie Zhuo
quotes.context: A concrete mental model for modern management as orchestrating a portfolio of AI tools/models against a clear vision.

quotes.topic_title: AI, org flattening, and managing models
quotes.text: It's always been manager's job to manage change. I just think the rate of change is accelerating. Today management is really about this idea of be sturdy while being flexible.
quotes.speaker: Julie Zhuo
quotes.context: Actionable guidance for managers to prioritize resilience and adaptability as the core competency in faster-changing environments.

quotes.topic_title: AI, org flattening, and managing models
quotes.text: You want to diagnose with data and treat with design.
quotes.speaker: Julie Zhuo
quotes.context: A memorable methodology for using analytics to find problems while relying on design to craft solutions.

quotes.topic_title: AI, org flattening, and managing models
quotes.text: I don't actually think a lot of the fast growing companies are using data well at this point. Traditionally things just didn't grow that fast. These companies are totally getting by on just good instincts and good vibes, but what always happens is eventually things stop growing.
quotes.speaker: Julie Zhuo
quotes.context: A contrarian warning that rapid growth can mask weak data practices until scaling forces a reckoning.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Having worked at a mega large corp like Meta as head of design and now as a founder at a tiny startup that's all about using data to help you make decisions, it's really rare for someone to have this spectrum of experiences.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Highlights the uncommon advantage of spanning big-company and startup contexts, especially for decision-making and leadership.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: In our conversation, we talk about how learning to be a great manager directly translates to learning how to use AI tools extremely well, which specific skills will become more valuable in the next couple of years, her most valuable and timeless advice for new managers, why she's not hiring product managers at her startup, her simple heuristic for knowing when to use data and when to use intuition in making decisions.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Previews several actionable, practitioner-relevant frameworks (AI skill transfer, hiring stance, and a data-vs-intuition heuristic).

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Julie was the longtime head of design for the Facebook app used by over three billion people.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A concrete scale data point that underscores the operational and leadership complexity behind her experience.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Sending wires, tracking spend, giving people on my team access to move money around, so freaking easy.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights a practical operating principle for finance tools: make core workflows (payments, spend visibility, delegated access) frictionless.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: And Mercury brings all the ways that you use money into a single product, including credit cards, invoicing, bill pay, reimbursements for your teammates and capital.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A clear “consolidate workflows into one system” model for reducing tool sprawl and improving financial operations.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: To thrive in the AI era, organizations need to adapt quickly, but many organization leaders struggle to answer pressing questions like which tools are working, how are they being used, what's actually driving value?
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Frames a measurement problem leaders can act on: instrument AI/tool adoption to connect usage to value, not just rollout.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: See what over 200,000 entrepreneurs love about Mercury.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Provides a concrete adoption data point that can be used as a credibility/traction benchmark when evaluating vendors.

quotes.topic_title: Reconnecting and podcast growth reflections
quotes.text: And so I've just kind of kept this fireplace across every studio I've moved across in my various places.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A concrete example of creating a consistent, recognizable “signature” element across changes—useful for brand continuity as formats and settings evolve.

quotes.topic_title: Reconnecting and podcast growth reflections
quotes.text: I even remember we chatted. Video was kind of a newer thing. You're like, "We'll record it, but it's really about the audio." And now we moved into the video era.
quotes.speaker: Julie Zhuo
quotes.context: Highlights how quickly distribution formats shift, and the importance of adapting content strategy from audio-first to video-inclusive over time.

quotes.topic_title: Reconnecting and podcast growth reflections
quotes.text: So since that first episode, this podcast has done over 20 million downloads. It's approaching 30 million downloads.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A specific growth data point that quantifies long-term compounding from consistent publishing over multiple years.

quotes.topic_title: Reconnecting and podcast growth reflections
quotes.text: I think it is a testament to just your curiosity and how much you really care about the craft of building great products and sharing that with the world.
quotes.speaker: Julie Zhuo
quotes.context: Points to a repeatable driver of audience trust—deep curiosity plus craft focus—as a practical north star for content and community building.

quotes.topic_title: The Making of a Manager success
quotes.text: My big motivation to write it was I think largely because I felt if I had to write this thing, I was likely going to become a better manager.
quotes.speaker: Julie Zhuo
quotes.context: A practical self-improvement method: committing to writing forces clarity and accelerates skill development.

quotes.topic_title: The Making of a Manager success
quotes.text: And I know that part of my process is when I really sit down to try and put down everything I feel and write letters to myself, it really helps me.
quotes.speaker: Julie Zhuo
quotes.context: A concrete reflective practice (“write letters to myself”) that practitioners can adopt to improve decision-making and self-awareness.

quotes.topic_title: The Making of a Manager success
quotes.text: I couldn't have expected that it would have much wider reach than that and that's been really awesome.
quotes.speaker: Julie Zhuo
quotes.context: A counterintuitive lesson about audience: writing for a specific context can still resonate far beyond it.

quotes.topic_title: The Making of a Manager success
quotes.text: And just how many people will tell me things like I thought I was the only one who felt this way, but this book made me realize that, hey, these are very normal feelings.
quotes.speaker: Julie Zhuo
quotes.context: Highlights the value of normalizing common insecurities—useful for leaders aiming to reduce imposter syndrome on teams.

quotes.topic_title: The Making of a Manager success
quotes.text: And that's certainly how I felt, just stumbling through and feeling like an imposter for so many years.
quotes.speaker: Julie Zhuo
quotes.context: A memorable admission that reframes early management struggles as common and survivable, not a personal failing.

quotes.topic_title: Managing AI agents like managing teams
quotes.text: management is just about, in my mind, having an outcome. So you want to get something done. That's the thing. You have a north star, you have a vision, and you're just trying to figure out how to use the resources that you have to get that thing done.
quotes.speaker: Julie Zhuo
quotes.context: Defines management as an outcome-driven discipline, a transferable mental model for directing AI agents toward clear results.

quotes.topic_title: Managing AI agents like managing teams
quotes.text: The second lever is around, okay, what's the purpose? Does everyone know what they're supposed to do with their talents? Do we have a goal? Do we have a purpose? And then the third thing is process, which is how should all of these different people and tools come together?
quotes.speaker: Julie Zhuo
quotes.context: Offers a practical three-lever framework (resources/talent, purpose, process) that maps directly onto orchestrating agents and tools.

quotes.topic_title: Managing AI agents like managing teams
quotes.text: You need to be very clear about what the outcome is and you have to understand the strengths of, used to be people, but now it's basically models. And different models have different strengths, so it's like they have different personalities.
quotes.speaker: Julie Zhuo
quotes.context: Actionable guidance for model selection: treat models as having distinct strengths and match them to tasks like you would with team members.

quotes.topic_title: Managing AI agents like managing teams
quotes.text: I think it's still very important for us to be able to provide the right context, provide the right high level instruction so that we get what we want.
quotes.speaker: Julie Zhuo
quotes.context: Emphasizes that even as agents get smarter, outcomes still depend on humans supplying context and high-level direction.

quotes.topic_title: Key skill: defining success with clarity
quotes.text: The first is defining the goal and defining the outcome and being really, really crystal clear on what does success look like.
quotes.speaker: Julie Zhuo
quotes.context: A core, actionable management skill for both humans and AI agents: start by making success criteria unambiguous.

quotes.topic_title: Key skill: defining success with clarity
quotes.text: I think a lot of times when you talk about why is alignment so difficult at a big company, it often comes down to this question, which is different people may have different pictures of what success looks like.
quotes.speaker: Julie Zhuo
quotes.context: A practical alignment diagnosis: misalignment often stems less from execution and more from mismatched definitions of success.

quotes.topic_title: Key skill: defining success with clarity
quotes.text: How do we get even more specific so that we know without question whether we've hit it or not.
quotes.speaker: Julie Zhuo
quotes.context: A test for clarity that practitioners can apply: define outcomes so you can decisively evaluate success vs. failure.

quotes.topic_title: Key skill: defining success with clarity
quotes.text: So figuring out how to boil it down so that an agent can really understand what success and failure looks like is a lot of the game.
quotes.speaker: Julie Zhuo
quotes.context: A concrete methodology for working with agents: translate high-level intent into explicit success/failure criteria.

quotes.topic_title: Key skill: defining success with clarity
quotes.text: And the forever question goes the whole point of data and the whole point of metrics and KPIs is we're trying to put a little bit more of an objective measure or get as crystal clear as possible about what success looks like.
quotes.speaker: Julie Zhuo
quotes.context: A memorable framing of metrics/KPIs as tools for operationalizing clarity and objective evaluation.

quotes.topic_title: Flattening orgs and the rise of builders
quotes.text: So I think the real promise and magic of AI that we're seeing in the workplace is that it leads us to each individual is far more empowered.
quotes.speaker: Julie Zhuo
quotes.context: Frames AI’s core workplace impact as individual leverage, setting up why orgs can flatten and roles can broaden.

quotes.topic_title: Flattening orgs and the rise of builders
quotes.text: Now, I'm not going to do them at what's called the PhD or the highest 1%, 10% level, but if I was at the zero or 10th percentile, it can certainly get me even today very quickly up to the 60th, 70th in terms of what the state of the art is.
quotes.speaker: Julie Zhuo
quotes.context: A concrete mental model for how AI shifts capability: rapid competence lift even without deep specialization.

quotes.topic_title: Flattening orgs and the rise of builders
quotes.text: we need to dissolve the boundaries of these traditional roles.
quotes.speaker: Julie Zhuo
quotes.context: Actionable guidance to redesign teams around outcomes rather than rigid job lanes.

quotes.topic_title: Flattening orgs and the rise of builders
quotes.text: So in some ways we can drop all of these different role distinctions and call ourselves builders.
quotes.speaker: Julie Zhuo
quotes.context: Introduces a memorable “builder” identity as a unifying model for cross-disciplinary work in AI-enabled teams.

quotes.topic_title: Flattening orgs and the rise of builders
quotes.text: we have eliminated more roles. For example, we thought we would need a bunch of product managers. It's turned out that actually if you don't have a product manager,
quotes.speaker: Julie Zhuo
quotes.context: A counterintuitive real-world example of flattening: removing a traditional role to encourage broader ownership.

quotes.topic_title: Why Sundial isn’t hiring product managers
quotes.text: It's turned out that actually if you don't have a product manager, I know this might be going against a little bit of the ethos of where Lenny started, but I find that sometimes when you have a designer or a product manager, and let's say I'm an engineer, then when I have a problem, like I need to figure out the product definition, my default will be, well, I've got these people and that's kind of their job description, so I'm just going to delegate that to them.
quotes.speaker: Julie Zhuo
quotes.context: Contrarian take that removing a PM role can prevent delegation-by-default and force deeper product ownership from engineers.

quotes.topic_title: Why Sundial isn’t hiring product managers
quotes.text: And so we found that if we actually make teams smaller and we even in the past, pre-AI, just have fewer of these, it allowed everyone to be like, "Wait, we don't have product manager on the team, so communication's up to me. Figuring out how we get greatest value to users is something that is now strictly in my charter.
quotes.speaker: Julie Zhuo
quotes.context: Actionable org-design lever: smaller teams and fewer specialized roles can increase individual accountability for user value and communication.

quotes.topic_title: Why Sundial isn’t hiring product managers
quotes.text: And I find that whenever you have teams and you empower them to be able to take more action on their specific context rather than having these higher level of rules or policies or this is how it's supposed to be, then you get better work. You get faster work and you get happier employees because people feel like they actually can have the power to create the thing that they want.
quotes.speaker: Julie Zhuo
quotes.context: A management principle linking context-driven empowerment (vs. rigid policies) to speed, quality, and morale.

quotes.topic_title: Why Sundial isn’t hiring product managers
quotes.text: So that skill is still important and the team still needs to have that skill, otherwise it's probably not going to produce the best outcome. But I like to think of it as what are the skills that are needed for this and can we now find a couple people?
quotes.speaker: Julie Zhuo
quotes.context: A skills-over-titles hiring and team-composition model: ensure critical product-thinking skills exist on the team, regardless of role labels.

quotes.topic_title: Generalist engineers and AI-assisted skill expansion
quotes.text: But it doesn't mean we just automatically go to that script of need a PM, need a designer, need three engineers, need that.
quotes.speaker: Julie Zhuo
quotes.context: Challenges default team-composition “scripts” and encourages staffing based on actual skill needs rather than roles.

quotes.topic_title: Generalist engineers and AI-assisted skill expansion
quotes.text: But if you say, look, you're an engineer, you're a builder, this has a little bit of front end, but you know what? You can probably figure that out. Use AI to help you figure it out. Get obviously someone who's a specialist to review the code or to give you some high level guidance on things, but just do it.
quotes.speaker: Julie Zhuo
quotes.context: A practical methodology for expanding engineers across domains using AI plus lightweight specialist review.

quotes.topic_title: Generalist engineers and AI-assisted skill expansion
quotes.text: They have to learn, so initially things take longer, takes a little bit of extra time, versus if you did slot in a front-end specialist and this is a front end project.
quotes.speaker: Julie Zhuo
quotes.context: Highlights the intentional short-term productivity tradeoff required to build broader capability.

quotes.topic_title: Generalist engineers and AI-assisted skill expansion
quotes.text: but in the long run that investment really pays off because now you have a lot more people who are, again, a little more well rounded and can take on many more pieces just on their own.
quotes.speaker: Julie Zhuo
quotes.context: Explains the long-term payoff: increased team flexibility and speed through more well-rounded contributors.

quotes.topic_title: Generalist engineers and AI-assisted skill expansion
quotes.text: And so it's really lovely to see that blend of everyone can do a little bit of everything else and we're all encouraging each other.
quotes.speaker: Julie Zhuo
quotes.context: Describes a cross-functional operating model where AI enables broader participation and mutual upskilling.

quotes.topic_title: AI as a personalized teacher for teams
quotes.text: And in fact, I think these days ChatGPT or these other AI tools are better teachers.
quotes.speaker: Julie Zhuo
quotes.context: A contrarian reframing that AI can outperform humans for many teaching/explaining tasks, reducing dependency on teammates’ time.

quotes.topic_title: AI as a personalized teacher for teams
quotes.text: Sometimes what I'll do is I'll find a curriculum online. And if you take a course, it'll be like this 12 week curriculum and I'll just feed it into ChatGPT and I'll say, "Help me customize a program for me using the ways that I like to learn."
quotes.speaker: Julie Zhuo
quotes.context: A concrete, repeatable method for turning generic learning resources into a personalized training plan using AI.

quotes.topic_title: AI as a personalized teacher for teams
quotes.text: We're different types of learners and so the idea of a tool that personalizes learning for each of us really helps us, I think, accelerate and just learn these skills much faster than before.
quotes.speaker: Julie Zhuo
quotes.context: A team-level learning model: use AI to tailor explanations to individual learning styles to speed up skill acquisition.

quotes.topic_title: AI as a personalized teacher for teams
quotes.text: So explains a bunch of things. And so what I often like to do is like, "Okay, I read this, so this..." I try to explain back what I heard. "So does this mean... Is that right way to think about it, that this is kind of like this analogy?" And ChatGPT will critique me.
quotes.speaker: Julie Zhuo
quotes.context: An actionable technique for validating understanding: “teach back” to the AI and use its critique as interactive feedback.

quotes.topic_title: AI as a personalized teacher for teams
quotes.text: But it helps so much because it's interactive and so we can really test whether we really understand the concept by trying to retell it back in our own way.
quotes.speaker: Julie Zhuo
quotes.context: A memorable learning principle: use interactivity to test comprehension, not just consume explanations.

quotes.topic_title: How fast-growing AI companies use data poorly
quotes.text: I don't actually think a lot of the fast-growing companies are using data well at this point.
quotes.speaker: Julie Zhuo
quotes.context: Contrarian take that hypergrowth can mask weak data practices, prompting leaders to reassess assumptions about “data-driven” AI companies.

quotes.topic_title: How fast-growing AI companies use data poorly
quotes.text: And so today we see companies that are growing insane and there's still about 10 people or two people or however many people, but they've got hundreds of millions in ARR and hundreds of millions of users.
quotes.speaker: Julie Zhuo
quotes.context: Concrete example of the scale/organizational mismatch that explains why instrumentation and observability often lag in AI hypergrowth startups.

quotes.topic_title: How fast-growing AI companies use data poorly
quotes.text: If you don't have good observability over how your business runs and what the company's key levers are, then you will be scrambling, and at that point, that's usually when people start investing a ton in data.
quotes.speaker: Julie Zhuo
quotes.context: Actionable warning to invest in observability early—before growth stalls and the team is forced into reactive analytics.

quotes.topic_title: How fast-growing AI companies use data poorly
quotes.text: Analysis has to answer the questions that we have, and if technology changes or context changes, we need new methodologies of analysis.
quotes.speaker: Julie Zhuo
quotes.context: A reusable framework: analytics methods must evolve with product paradigms (e.g., from mobile to conversational AI).

quotes.topic_title: How fast-growing AI companies use data poorly
quotes.text: Conversational analytics is totally different.
quotes.speaker: Julie Zhuo
quotes.context: Highlights a key methodological shift for AI products: traditional click-based metrics don’t map cleanly to chat-based experiences.

quotes.topic_title: Designers, data skepticism, and a balanced framework
quotes.text: what you really want is you want to diagnose with data and treat with design.
quotes.speaker: Julie Zhuo
quotes.context: A memorable framework for balancing analytics (to find/understand problems) with design (to create solutions).

quotes.topic_title: Designers, data skepticism, and a balanced framework
quotes.text: So data is not a tool that's going to tell you what you should build or what the solution is or how we're going to cure the fact that you don't have really great retention. It's just not. But it can tell you if you have a problem and where that problem or opportunity might be. But you still need to go back and undergo a very creative process to figure out what's the best way to solve that.
quotes.speaker: Julie Zhuo
quotes.context: Actionable guidance on using data to locate issues/opportunities while relying on creative design work to generate the fix.

quotes.topic_title: Designers, data skepticism, and a balanced framework
quotes.text: To me data is also, well, what did people put onto TikTok and which things went viral, and what are they saying in the Twitter verse or X verse I guess is what it's called now.
quotes.speaker: Julie Zhuo
quotes.context: Expands “data” beyond dashboards and A/B tests to include qualitative signals from real-world user behavior and discourse.

quotes.topic_title: Designers, data skepticism, and a balanced framework
quotes.text: Because it's like, okay, we got these numbers and the numbers go up. It's like no, the fact that you still have to choose which things you look at, is an art, not a science. And your interpretation of if the number went up 5%, is that good, is that not good, is also an interpretation and is an art, not a science.
quotes.speaker: Julie Zhuo
quotes.context: A counterintuitive warning against “false precision,” emphasizing that metric selection and interpretation require judgment.

quotes.topic_title: Designers, data skepticism, and a balanced framework
quotes.text: So the other thing I would say that I really support is you just actually can't make a really great product by thinking you can A-B test your way into it.
quotes.speaker: Julie Zhuo
quotes.context: Challenges the common belief that experimentation alone can produce excellence, reinforcing the need for design-led invention.

quotes.topic_title: Managing accelerating change with willow-tree leadership
quotes.text: I think that managing change. It's always been manager's job to manage change, and there's always the chaos of what's going on. I just think the rate of change is accelerating, and we've seen that over the last couple of decades.
quotes.speaker: Julie Zhuo
quotes.context: Reframes the manager’s core responsibility as change management, with AI making the pace of change the defining challenge.

quotes.topic_title: Managing accelerating change with willow-tree leadership
quotes.text: So I think today, management is really about this idea of be sturdy while being flexible, and that is a very hard thing to pull off, but I think that's at least when I even go into... I'm like, "Be like the willow tree, Julie. Just imagine the willow tree and try and channel that as the kind of feeling of what it is that we're trying to do together."
quotes.speaker: Julie Zhuo
quotes.context: Offers a memorable “willow tree” mental model for leading through volatility: resilient principles with adaptable tactics.

quotes.topic_title: Managing accelerating change with willow-tree leadership
quotes.text: I think if you don't think it's good, it's kind of a painful way to live. It'll be very, very difficult over these next. So I do think that all things be equal, lean into it.
quotes.speaker: Julie Zhuo
quotes.context: Actionable mindset advice for sustaining leadership energy: default to embracing change rather than resisting it.

quotes.topic_title: Managing accelerating change with willow-tree leadership
quotes.text: And I think if managers who try to pretend like it isn't there, it's all good, no one's upset, et cetera, there's something also missing about just addressing and being able to be like, yeah, it's hard. Change is hard. We're probably going to get upset. We're going to have some chaos. This is going to happen, but we will work through it because we're going to be flexible and we're going to be able to put our eyes on the big picture of what is possible, which is exciting.
quotes.speaker: Julie Zhuo
quotes.context: Balances optimism with emotional realism: acknowledge fear and chaos explicitly while anchoring the team on adaptability and possibility.

quotes.topic_title: Timeless management lesson: manage yourself first
quotes.text: The first thing that comes to mind is the importance of managing yourself and understanding yourself.
quotes.speaker: Julie Zhuo
quotes.context: Frames effective management as starting with self-management and self-awareness before managing others.

quotes.topic_title: Timeless management lesson: manage yourself first
quotes.text: And I am a very big believer that every strength is its own weakness, and every weakness is a strength.
quotes.speaker: Julie Zhuo
quotes.context: A counterintuitive lens for interpreting strengths/weaknesses that helps leaders avoid one-dimensional self-assessments.

quotes.topic_title: Timeless management lesson: manage yourself first
quotes.text: So what dimensionality means is you're a human being, but we can kind of look at you in infinite dimensions.
quotes.speaker: Julie Zhuo
quotes.context: Introduces a “dimensionality” framework for separating identity from performance across many skills and contexts.

quotes.topic_title: Timeless management lesson: manage yourself first
quotes.text: And ideally you're not like, "Julie is saying I'm a bad person, my identity is at risk," right? Because it's just one dimension of who you are.
quotes.speaker: Julie Zhuo
quotes.context: Shows how the dimensionality model reduces defensiveness by treating feedback as about a specific dimension, not personal worth.

quotes.topic_title: Timeless management lesson: manage yourself first
quotes.text: somebody can give you feedback or you can be maybe not great at certain dimensions, you can have room to improve, and that's not who you are because you are all of these infinite dimensions in one, and none of them is representative of your true worth as an individual.
quotes.speaker: Julie Zhuo
quotes.context: A practical reframing that helps leaders and teams receive feedback productively without tying it to identity.
